summary: S. D. Breckinridge appears as the author of memoranda within the CIA. The documents suggest Breckinridge was involved in internal administrative matters and investigations. Specifically, Breckinridge requested photographs of Agency employees with the surname Bishop in 1978 to assist witnesses in identifying a person named Morris Bishop. Breckinridge was also involved in investigations related to E. Howard Hunt's activities, particularly his assignment in Madrid during the mid-1960s, focusing on financial transactions and operational roles. The documents also show involvement in the handling of the Yuriy Nosenko case and concerns regarding the release of information related to Nosenko in connection with the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act.
significance: S. D. Breckinridge's significance in the JFK context stems from involvement in the handling of the Yuriy Nosenko case and concerns regarding the release of information related to Nosenko in connection with the JFK Assassination Records Collection Act. The documents suggest an administrative role within the CIA, dealing with internal investigations and information management related to individuals and events of interest to the JFK assassination investigation.
